Technical Fellow & Chief Architect for the Azure Infrastructure and Management Team
This team is responsible for Azure Stack, Operations Management Suite, System Center, Azure Portal,  Azure HW, and PowerShell for Windows and Linux.
Technical Fellow & Chief Architect for the Enterprise Cloud Group and the Microsoft Azure Stack
Responsibilities include Windows Server, Azure Stack, Operations Management Suite, System Center, and PowerShell.
Distinguished Engineer/Lead Architect Windows Server and System Center Datacenter

Lead the creation, evangelization and execution of the overall Windows Server and System Center technical strategy.Drove specific technical initiatives around the datacenter abstraction layer (DAL), modern cloud fabric, standards-based management and automation.Transformed complex, multi-year aspirational goals into sequences of short term deliverables with clear value propositions.Technical adviser and approver of the Common Engineering Criteria program to deliver a common customer experience.Company spokesperson with press, partners, analysts and customers.

recommendations: Héritier Kandolo
MCT and Instructor IT Essential  at ESIS - Cisco and Microsoft Academy
December 30, 2016, Héritier was Jeffrey’s mentor

I like to call it JSNover. I learned Powershell through its course "Juping Start Powershell v3.0" on Microsoft Virtual Academy. It gave me the taste of Microsoft Powershell with its teaching methodology. Eg: ii "e: \ Scripting Files". A command that I use to the quontidien. This is one person I will not hesitate to recommend to companies.

Vickie R. Comrie, MISM
Enrolled in MicroMaster's Certification in UX/UI Design, Research and Strategy from U of M/edx.org
December 1, 2011, Vickie R. was a client of Jeffrey’s

I had the pleasure of hearing Jeffrey speak about Power Shell at the recent Dev Connections 2011 conference in Las Vegas.   I had never heard of Power Shell before Jeffrey’s talk, but by the end, Jeffrey had converted me to the point that I decided I had to learn at least the basics of this technology—as a Windows user, novice developer, and as someone who will be re-entering the work force seeking new and valuable skills to differentiate myself from the pack.  Power Shell is an incredibly useful tool that allows users to automate and control tasks and applications that run on Windows.  Anyone working with the Windows operating system would be remiss in not making themselves familiar with an application that makes one’s administration work easier and more efficient.  Jeffrey introduced this technology in a way that explained the basics to a novice such as myself, yet simultaneously brought expert level users up to date with the changes in Power Shell, through his mastery of blending everyday language with complex technological terminology--an especially useful skill when speaking in front of an audience comprised of people with mixed abilities and levels of competence.  My attention never drifted for a moment as I listened to Jeffrey’s presentation.  His presentation was fascinating, his speaking style engaging and charming.  I would highly recommend Jeffrey as a speaker or presenter regarding any area of his vast expertise.
Vickie R. Comrie, MISM
Enrolled in MicroMaster's Certification in UX/UI Design, Research and Strategy from U of M/edx.org

Kendall Lock
Vice President, IBM Public Cloud
November 6, 2016, Jeffrey reported directly to Kendall

Kendall is a highly effective executive with a strong track record of managing difficult situations to success.  He creates clarity and energy which enables teams to deliver.I both worked for Kendall and worked with him as a peer at Tivoli between 1998 and 2000.  Kendall has the ability to take a wide range of goals, constraints and concerns and transform them into a coherent and compelling plan that was communicated in a clear and concise way.  Kendall's clarity and energy enabled his teams to prioritize their work and work independently and effectively towards a common goal.  When conflicts arose, Kendall resolved them quickly and decisively.  More importantly, he did so grounding his decisions in a set of clear principals which provided both transparency and allowed teams to auto-resolve other issues.I worked with Kendall during the internet bubble where organizations hemorrhaged people to startup companies. Tivoli was no exception and our project was rocked many times with waves of people leaving - often at the worst times possible. I've never been more impressed with a manager than I was watching Kendall manage this very difficult period.  Kendall *managed* the situation.  There was no drama.  Kendall would come to  work in the morning and face yet another wave of difficult news.  For him was  just a new set of facts.  He looked at what our goals were, looked at the options before him and generated a new set of facts that allowed him to achieve our goals.  The range of difficult situations we encountered were almost absurd and yet step by step, Kendall managed the situation effectively with clarity and composure. Again - I consider Kendall to be the gold standard of effective executives.I worked for Kendall as an architect. Kendall is very technical and would often have me drill into the details of particular issues. That said, he struck a great balance between involved and empowering. He wanted to understand the details and the ramifications and the empowered me to make a set of decisions.  He was not shy to override my calls when he had data/context that I did not.  That never felt good but when it occurred but when it did, Kendall was firm, gracious, and generous with his time to explain his decision making and provide the missing data/context.  In doing so, he made it easy for me to support the new approach with conviction and gave me a new set of things to think about as I made my decisions.  He made me a better architect.As I said above - I consider Kendall to be the gold standard of effective executives.

June Blender
Senior Technical Writer at Amazon Web Services
July 20, 2014, Jeffrey worked with June in different groups

June is one of the best technical writers that I have ever worked with and I consider June a partner in making PowerShell what it is today.  When I met June, she had so many great ideas about how to better engage with customers that I had to have her work on PowerShell.  I worked with June for many years and in addition to being a great writer, she was always an incredible advocate for our customers.  She spent a lot of time with actual customers both telling them about our products and listening for how to make both the documentation and the product better.  Many of the things in PowerShell are extremely technical and June did a great job understanding them and suggesting ways to simplify things.  When June had an idea, everyone on the team would stop and listen.  That is not to say that we always agreed but we always took to time to evaluate her recommendations.  In those discussions, June made clear and concise arguments for her position and then fully committed herself to plan whether it went her way or not.  June's ability to work with a wide range of engineers, quickly come up to speed on highly technical subjects, develop strategies for documenting them successfully, engagement with the customer community and ability to drive customer feedback into product development, made June one of the best partners we had in making PowerShell a success.  I cannot say enough positive things about June and her contributions to PowerShell and the PowerShell community.
June Blender
